title: What is a Linked List?
contentText: A linked list is a linear data structure made of nodes. Each node stores data and a reference to the next node.

title: Singly Linked List
contentText: Each node points only to the next node. Traversal is one-directional from head to tail.

title: Doubly Linked List
contentText: Each node stores references to both next and previous nodes. This allows forward and backward traversal.

title: Circular Linked List
contentText: In a circular linked list, the last node points back to the head, creating a loop structure.

title: Advantages and Drawbacks
contentText: Insertion and deletion are efficient when node references are known. Random access is slower than arrays because traversal is sequential.

title: Use Cases
contentText: Linked lists are used for dynamic memory structures, implementing stacks/queues, and adjacency representations in graphs.
